qas.question: Why have aircraft carriers increased in size since World War II?

answers.text: to accommodate a steady increase in aircraft size

qas.question: How much more displacement does the modern Nimitz class have compared to the older USS Enterprise?
Why do nations risk significant political impacts if a carrier is lost or even used in conflict?

answers.text: Today's aircraft carriers are so expensive

qas.question: Which era does the USS Enterprise belong to?

plausible_answers.text: to accommodate a steady increase in aircraft size

qas.question: Why have aircraft carriers increased in size since World War I?

plausible_answers.text: Today's aircraft carriers are so expensive

qas.question: Why do nations risk minimal political impacts if a carrier is lost or even used in conflict?

plausible_answers.text: significant political, economic, and military impact if a carrier is lost

qas.question: Today's aircraft carriers are so cheap that nations which operate them risk what?

context: Since World War II, aircraft carrier designs have increased in size <a0_0><b4_0>to accommodate a steady increase in aircraft size<b4_0/><a0_0/>. The large, modern Nimitz class of US carriers has a displacement <a1_0><b5_0>nearly four times<b5_0/><a1_0/> that of the <a3_0><b7_0>World War II<b7_0/><a3_0/>–era USS Enterprise, yet its complement of aircraft is roughly the same—a consequence of the steadily increasing size and weight of military aircraft over the years. <a2_0><b6_0>Today's aircraft carriers are so expensive<b6_0/><a2_0/> that nations which operate them risk <b8_0>significant political, economic, and military impact if a carrier is lost<b8_0/>, or even used in conflict.
